Authors:
Xian Zhou, Meng Pan, Haoyu Li, Cheng Ming Tian, Long Fei
Fan
Title:
Dieback of Euonymus alatus (Celastraceae) caused by Cytospora
haidianensis sp. nov. in China
Keywords:
Cytosporaceae; Diaporthales; mycelial growth;
pathogenicity; phylogeny; taxonomy
Abstract:
Euonymus alatus (Celastraceae) is largely cultivated in
China owing to the economic value and landscape benefits. Euonymus
alatus dieback came out by members of Cytospora and it has become one of
the most severe diseases affecting the cultivation of E. alatus in
China. In this study, we examined the causal agent of bough dieback of
campuses of University Road, Beijing, China. Amongst the strains, three
of them were morphologically consistent with Cytospora showing hyaline
and allantoid conidia. Based on phylogenetic analyses of the
concatenated ACT, ITS, RPB2, TEF1-α and TUB2 gene sequences along with
morphological characteristics, we are proposing C. haidianensis as a
novel species. It was confirmed as causal agent of dieback on E. alatus
by pathogenicity tests. Mycelial growth of C. haidianensis occurred at
pH values ranging from 3.0 to 11.0, with an optimum growth at 8.3, and
at temperatures from 5 to 35 °C, with an optimum growth at 19.8 °C. We
also tested the growth of C. haidianensis in the presence of six carbon
sources. Sucrose, maltose and glucose were highly efficient and xylose
was the last one. The ability of C. haidianensis to grow at 19.8 °C may
help to explain its occurrence causing dieback on E. alatus in Beijing
during the autumn season.
